entries.title: Russian Proxies in Ukraine Push Moscow to Annex Occupied Regions
entries.description: The requests lent an air of formality to a process condemned by the West. They followed sham referendums in four regions in Ukraine that purported to put voters’ stamp of approval on joining Russia.

entries.title: The Pentagon announces an additional $1.1 billion in long-term aid for Ukraine.
At least 150,000 Leave Russia After Putin Announced Partial Military Mobilization
Why Experts and Officials Say Nord Stream Pipleline Leaks Were No Accident
What We Know About the Mysterious Pipeline Leaks Between Russia and Europe
entries.description: The leaks, which may amount to as much as a third of Denmark’s annual carbon emissions, expose the vulnerability of critical infrastructure as the war in Ukraine continues.

entries.title: Sabotaged Pipelines and a Mystery: Who Did It?
entries.description: An attack on gas lines under the Baltic Sea exposes the vulnerability of an already jittery Europe. Some officials suggested Moscow was to blame, but with little evidence, others urge caution.

entries.title: A mystery hovers over the apparent sabotage of two undersea gas pipelines: Did Russia do it?
At the United Nations, Zelensky rails against Russia for trying to ‘steal’ Ukrainian territory.
Your Thursday Briefing: Iran Strikes Kurds in Iraq
entries.description: Plus Australia moves to fight corruption and a Chinese businessman faces assault allegations in a U.S. court.

entries.title: The top E.U. diplomat says the Nord Stream leaks resulted from ‘a deliberate act.’
Moscow Releases Final Results of Discredited Ukraine Referendums
Meeting in Brussels Signifies a Turning Point for Allies Arming Ukraine
entries.description: Defense officials responsible for purchasing weapons for more than 40 nations discussed how to ramp up production for a potentially yearslong war.

entries.title: 4 Palestinians Killed in West Bank During Israeli Raid
entries.description: The militants were among more than 90 Palestinians and two Israeli security officials killed in the territory in 2022, as violence continues to surge.

entries.title: Protests in Prague Signal a Troubled Winter Ahead in Europe
entries.description: Tens of thousands gathered in the Czech capital for the second such protest in a month, spurred by an energy crisis and rising prices that are affecting countries across Europe.

entries.title: Guinea 2009 Massacre Trial Begins
entries.description: In addition to those killed, dozens of women were raped when security forces stormed a pro-democracy rally in 2009, a U.N. investigation found. Eleven men, including the country’s former president, are on trial.

entries.title: Tensions in Iran Spill Across the Border Into Iraq
entries.description: The Revolutionary Guards Corps has been attacking Kurdish opposition groups in northern Iraq, blaming them for fomenting the unrest in Iran that was set off by the death of Mahsa Amini.

entries.title: If Brazil’s President Attempts a Coup, What Will the Police Do?
entries.description: If Brazil’s election sparks mass unrest, the country’s so-called military police force would be called upon to restore order, giving them tremendous power to affect outcomes.

entries.title: Few South Koreans Are Having Babies. A Mayor’s Answer? More Nannies.
entries.description: The mayor of Seoul wants to ease the high cost and low supply of babysitters in the country to encourage more couples to have children.

entries.title: Russian-backed officials ask Putin to annex Ukrainian regions after referendums that were widely dismissed as a sham.
entries.description: The appeals from Moscow-backed leaders set in motion formalities intended to give Russia’s plans a sheen of legitimacy.

entries.title: Why Experts and Officials Say Nord Stream Pipleline Leaks Were No Accident
Covid Boosters
entries.description: Who should get a Covid booster, and when? We answer the big questions.

entries.title: Australia’s Proposed Integrity Commission Would Work Mostly in Secret
entries.description: Fulfilling a campaign promise, the government has a plan for an oversight agency to investigate allegations of corruption. Many welcome the move, but not unreservedly.

entries.title: Cuba Starts Restoring Power After Hurricane Ian Causes Blackout
entries.description: Power began coming back on in the east, but it was not clear how much of the electricity had been restored by Wednesday morning.

entries.title: U.S. Mountaineer’s Body Found Two Days After Avalanche on Peak in Nepal
entries.description: Hilaree Nelson was apparently blown off a cliff while she was skiing down Manaslu, the world’s eighth-highest peak.

entries.title: Our Correspondents on the Biggest Music, Shows and Books in Their Parts of the World
entries.description: Keeping an eye on and ear out for breakout hits.

entries.title: Chinese Billionaire Richard Liu Faces Sexual Assault Trial in the US
entries.description: Richard Liu, also known as Liu Qiangdong, will be one of the few high-profile Chinese figures to face a courtroom jury over sexual assault allegations.

entries.title: Read Your Way Through Rome
entries.description: Igiaba Scego, an author born in Rome to Somali parents, recommends books that draw readers through the rich layers that make up her hometown.

entries.title: Far From Routine, Asia Trip Presents Thorny Tests for Kamala Harris
entries.description: A visit for Shinzo Abe’s controversial state funeral also includes outreach to Asian allies over military advances by North Korea and China.

entries.title: Zambia and Its New President Are Still on Their Honeymoon
entries.description: Hakainde Hichilema is hailed as a miracle worker for turning around the fortunes of the southern African country. But with his opposition neutralized and a corruption drive focused on his predecessors, some are uneasy.

entries.title: U.S. Will Lead Talks With Allies on Producing More Weapons
entries.description: Defense officials from dozens of countries are set to meet in Brussels to discuss longer-term demand for militaries all over the world.

entries.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
entries.description: Suspicious gas leaks in Europe.

entries.title: Pipeline breaks look deliberate, Europeans say, exposing vulnerability in vital energy infrastructure.
As Russians Flee, Some Find Draft Notices Waiting at the Border
entries.description: The Kremlin dispatched federal security forces to frontier border crossings packed with Russian men trying to escape the draft by entering countries like Georgia, Kazakhstan and Mongolia.
